data.title: Unable to git push since v1.21.0
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Since `v1.21.0` I get an error when I try to push my commits via the git window in atom.

```
error: cannot spawn .git/hooks/pre-push: No such file or directory
error: waitpid for .git/hooks/pre-push failed: No child processes
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://[url]/[project].git'
```

`v1.22.0-beta0` has the same issue.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Stage changes and create a commit
2. Click on `Push`

**Expected behavior:** It should push commits to remote without errors.

**Actual behavior:** The above error appears.

**Reproduces how often:** Always since `v1.21.0`

Previous versions are not affected.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.21.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS: Windows 10 x64

data.title: Atom will not start, will not install
data.body:
Windows 10 64 Bit

Atom version v1.21.0 (2017-10-03)

After an update today, several things occured. First the icon changed to the default application icon. Didn't think much of it.

After a restart, Atom won't open from terminal (Git for Windows) "atom" command. Decided to reinstall.

Attempted to reinstall using installer downloaded a week or two ago. Failed. Tried running installer as admin, failed. [https://i.imgur.com/5bzcWI8.png](https://i.imgur.com/5bzcWI8.png)

Uninstaller won't run, something about invalid uninstaller I think. Uninstalled using Revo Uninstaller.

Tried reinstalling, same failure message. Tried installing beta for giggles, same problem.

Here's the install log:
[http://paste.thezomg.com/23584/07097235/](http://paste.thezomg.com/23584/07097235/)

data.body:

### Description

Electron upgrade to 1.6.9+ causes dev tools to pause during autocomplete

3. type in something to auto complete.

Atom doesn't pause when using dev tools in console while being paused

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

/cc @Ben3eeE @nathansobo

data.title: Fix rendering bug when folds cause the vertical scrollbar to disappear with soft wrapping enabled
data.body:
Closes #15761
Closes #15549
Refs #15263

Due to the fact that the soft-wrapping boundary can change due to a variety of different factors (scrollbars appearing or disappearing, font size changes, editor dimensions changing, etc), we decided to detect changes in the soft-wrap boundary at the start of every frame before proceeding with any other rendering.

This works fine in principle, but prior to this PR it was causing us to write inconsistent values for the `firstRenderedScreenRow` to the per-frame derived dimensions cache in certain edge cases, causing rendering bugs downstream. This could occur when folding caused a document that was scrolled down partially to no longer be tall enough to scroll. This would cause the following unfortunate series of events:

* We would detect the scrollbar becoming invisible due to the shrinking of the content height below the editor height and update the soft-wrap width in [`updateModelSoftWrapColumn`](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3a3c58e04e37f3fe653d742134a0067bc8adb8dc/src/text-editor-component.js#L2099).
* Updating the soft wrap boundary would [*reset* the display layer](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3a3c58e04e37f3fe653d742134a0067bc8adb8dc/src/text-editor-component.js#L2104), causing it to recompute itself in the background.
* We would then then immediately compute the soft wrap boundary [a second time](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3a3c58e04e37f3fe653d742134a0067bc8adb8dc/src/text-editor-component.js#L2106). We always compute the soft wrap boundary twice because the initial change in the soft wrap boundary could change scroll bar visibility, which causes the soft wrap boundary to change again. Unfortunately, we were computing the soft wrap boundary *without* forcing a synchronous update for the visible row range of the display layer, and thus not accounting for the presence of the fold and assuming the scrollbar was visible again.
* In the process of computing the soft wrap boundary a second time, we were caching the incorrect values for the first rendered row in `derivedDimensionsCache`.
* Immediately following the update of the soft wrap boundary, we would [populate the display layer for visible row range](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3a3c58e04e37f3fe653d742134a0067bc8adb8dc/src/text-editor-component.js#L365), causing all future derived dimensions to be based on a correctly populated display layer. This would cause a mix of derived values cached against two different versions of the display layer, leading to inconsistent rendering state.

The solution in this PR is to

* Compute the first rendered row prior to resetting the display layer.
* After resetting the display layer, immediately force it to synchronously populate itself for the visible row range before making any additional computations.

These two steps ensure that the `derivedDimensionsCache` is never populated with inconsistent values. I'm hopeful that this issue was also the source of measurement exceptions in #15263, though we'll have to wait to be sure since we never have reproduced them.

Huge props to @ben3eee and @ungb for their help tracking down this edge case. Thanks so much.

data.title: Preserve indentation when toggling comments on whitespace-only lines
data.body:
Fixes a regression introduced in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/15713.

When toggling comments on whitespace-only lines, we need to preserve the indentation level.

/cc @jasonrudolph

data.title: Prompt to save when unloading if editor is in conflict
data.body:
Refs https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15791

Normally we don't prompt to save editors when reloading or closing a window. But if an editor's contents have changed on disk, then we would need to save the editor to avoid data loss.

I'm not positive that this is the best solution, but it seems reasonable to let you know that if you don't save, you'll lose your changes. Ultimately, we need a little more UI to surface the fact that the editor has changed on disk.

data.title: FR: Enable native/built-in spellchecking in atom
data.body:
The [atom spell-check package is really cool](https://github.com/atom/spell-check), but I think it would be great to enable builtin system spellcheck (e.g. macOS builtin spellcheck) to also be able to work through atom.  It seems that this would enable a smoother (and more native-feel) UX, in addition to reducing the overhead required of atom (and associated packages).  Already customized dictionaries from the system would then automatically apply without requiring additional customization.

Other references for the same idea:
- [discuss.atom.io](https://discuss.atom.io/t/can-atom-use-native-mac-os-x-spellchecking-dictionaries-or-ui/35527)
- [stackoverflow.com](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39698458/atom-native-macos-spell-check-and-autocorrect)

Related points:
- https://github.com/atom/spell-check/issues/11

data.title: Atom does not remember last-opened state if a spec window is closed last
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When a normal Atom window as well as an Atom spec window are open, closing the spec window last results in Atom attempting to save the state of the spec window rather than the actual project window.  Spec windows should probably be ignored when saving state.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open any project
2. Run specs using the GUI
3. Close the project window
4. Close the specs window
5. `atom` in terminal

**Expected behavior:** The project from step 1 to be reopened

**Actual behavior:** Atom appears un-maximized (same dimensions as the spec window) and with no project state.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-c30cc9bc8
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

This may be harder to reproduce on macOS due to its special Quit behavior.

data.title: Data loss when switching branches
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have a successful repro for a data loss scenario that can occur when switching branches while having unsaved changes on a file that has been modified on the branch you're switching to.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Checkout the `wl-data-loss` branch on [atom/language-html](https://github.com/atom/language-html)
2. Add the following code after line 354 (such that it lines up with the `it` on line 342 and has proper spacing):
```coffee
    describe "the 'style' attribute", ->
      beforeEach ->
        atom.packages.activatePackage('language-css')

      it "tokenizes the style attribute value as a CSS property list", ->
        tokens = grammar.tokenizeLine '<span style="color: red;">'

        expect(tokens[3]).toEqual value: 'style', scopes: ['text.html.basic', 'meta.tag.inline.span.html', 'meta.attribute-with-value.style.html', 'entity.other.attribute-name.style.html']
        expect(tokens[5]).toEqual value: '"', scopes: ['text.html.basic', 'meta.tag.inline.span.html', 'meta.attribute-with-value.style.html', 'string.quoted.double.html', 'punctuation.definition.string.begin.html']
        expect(tokens[6]).toEqual value: 'color', scopes: ['text.html.basic', 'meta.tag.inline.span.html', 'meta.attribute-with-value.style.html', 'source.css.style.html', 'meta.property-name.css', 'support.type.property-name.css']
```
I have also provided the modified file as a Gist here: https://gist.github.com/50Wliu/89ca9346904f8d9630e27ece49b52b8d
3. Checkout `wl-data-loss-here` _without saving the file_
4. Reload Atom

**Expected behavior:** Checkout to fail since there are unsaved changes and `html-spec.coffee` has been modified on `wl-data-loss-here`

**Actual behavior:** Checkout succeeds and shows the file as modified.  Upon reloading Atom, all unsaved changes are lost.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.23.0-dev-c30cc9bc8
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

Windows 10 x64.

/cc: @maxbrunsfeld @smashwilson

data.title: Cursor jumps, changes are reverted after IME composition pops up on input-disabled-editor.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When IME composition pops up on input-disabled-editor, it incorrectly create checkpoint.
After enable input and start insertion, buffer-state is reverted to wrongly created checkpoint(so cursor jumps, changes are reverted).

At final timing in GIF, text `a` is inserted elsewhere, and text-deletions are reverted.

![ime-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/31051857-69ddbd26-a6ae-11e7-9e6f-d5f7240cf547.gif)

**This is really critical issue for vim-mode-plus user who use IME(e.g. Japanese, Chinese)**
Since vim-mode-plus fundamentally depends on disable/enable input(`editor.component.setInputEnabled(true/false)`) to achieve modal-editing.

### Steps to Reproduce

##### Steps for explanatory purpose

1. Disable input `editor.component.setInputEnabled(false)`
2. Enable IME and pops up IME composition by entering some text.
3. Move cursor, also delete line by `editor:delete-line`(`ctrl-shift-K`).
4. Enable input `editor.composition.setInputEnabled(true)`.
5. Type some text to insert text.

At first char input timing.

- Char inserted at cursor position where last IME composition pop up happened.(position in step-2).
- Also all the buffer-text changes done after step-2 are **reverted**.


##### Steps for easy to observe.

1. Open non-empty editor.
2. Paste code bellow on chrome dev-console, at this point editor-input is disabled.

```javascript
(function emulateVimMode() {
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()
  editor.element.classList.add("vim-test")

  startInsert = () => {
    if (!editor.component.isInputEnabled()) {
      editor.component.setInputEnabled(true)
      console.log("start insert")
    }
  }
  stopInsert = () => {
    if (editor.component.isInputEnabled()) {
      editor.component.setInputEnabled(false)
      console.log("stop insert")
    }
  }

  atom.commands.add(editor.element, {
    "vim-test:start-insert": () => startInsert()
    "vim-test:stop-insert": () => stopInsert()
  })
  stopInsert()
})()
```

3. Enable IME and type some keys to make IME composition pops up then stop IME.
4. Move cursor, also delete line by `editor:delete-line`(`ctrl-shift-K`).
5. Enable input by executing `vim-test:start-insert` via command-palette.
6. Type some text to insert text.(see cursor jumps, changes are reverted)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Text is inserted at cursor position and changes are NOT reverted.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Text is inserted at different position and all changes are reverted.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% with safe-mode

### Versions

Issue not happens in v.1.18, so I believe this issue started after editor-rewrite.

- Could reproduce: v1.19.7, 1.20, 1.21-beta2

```
Atom    : 1.19.7
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.20.1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

```
Atom    : 1.21.0-beta2
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

- could NOT reproduce: v1.18.0(haven't check all patch versions)

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

- Original issue in vim-mode-plus
https://github.com/t9md/atom-vim-mode-plus/issues/875


Other reported issue like "content reverted" might shares same cause with this issue.
al
